translated: Jātaka🔽The Minor Collection
The Chapter with Pairs
The Great Owl Jātaka
“The owls, with their sharp beaks, are binding the fireflies in the island,🔽The people are hoping to eat me.
Tell me, Senaka, about a friend and companion,
Explain the destruction of the relatives of the birds.”
“You are the best of the birds, O bird,
I go for refuge to the king of owls.
The people are hoping to eat me,
The hunters with their sharp beaks, be my happiness.”
“The wise make friends and companions,
Seeking happiness in season and out of season.
I will do this for you, Senaka,
For the noble one does the duty for the noble one.”
“Whatever duty there is for the compassionate one,
This has been done by you, the noble one, for the noble one.

analyzed: attā anurakkhī bhava mā a dayhi
translated: Protect yourself, be not merciless,
We will obtain our young ones if you live.”
“Protecting you, my friend,
I will not be distressed even if my body breaks apart.
Some do the duty of friends for friends,
Sacrificing their lives, this is the duty of the good.”
“You have done a very difficult deed,
a bird living in an egg;
For the sake of the young, the curlew
at midnight, when it was not yet dawn.”

analyzed: cutā api heke khalitā sa kammunā
translated: “Some, though cut, do not waver in their duty,
they stand by their friends out of compassion;

analyzed: puttā mama aṭṭā gatim āgataḥ asmi
translated: I have come to a good destination because of my son,
do what is beneficial, my friend, my companion.”
“With wealth, with grain, and with themselves,
the wise make friends and companions;
I do this for you, Senaka,
for the noble one does the duty of the noble one.”
“Father, sit down, be not anxious;
a son does what is beneficial for his father;
I will do this for you,
protecting the sons of Senaka.”

analyzed: addhā hi tāta satama isa dhammo
translated: “Surely, father, this is the duty of the good,
that a son does what is beneficial for his father;
If they see me grown up,
the sons of Senaka will not harm me.”
“Animals, humans, and the best of deer and buffalo,
when frightened, take refuge in the best;

analyzed: puttā mama aṭṭā gatim āgataḥ asmi
translated: I have come to a good destination because of my son,

original: Tvaṁ nosi rājā bhava me sukhāya”.
analyzed: tvam na usi rājā bhava me sukhāya
translated: Be my king and bring me happiness.”
“I will do this for you, Senaka,
I will come to you for the sake of that region.
For how can a wise man, full of understanding,

analyzed: na vā āyame atta janassa guttiyā
translated: Not strive to protect his own people?”
“One should make friends and be kind-hearted,
And make friends for the sake of happiness.
Like a bird carrying off a piece of meat,
We rejoice with our children, being complete.
Because of the deed of a friend,
Of a companion who does not flee,
They cry out to one who is crying out,
With their hair on end, their hearts trembling.
The wise one, having obtained a friend and companion,

original: So bhuñjatī putta pasuṁ dhanaṁ vā;
analyzed: sā u bhuñjatī putta pasum dhanam vā
translated: He enjoys children, cattle, and wealth.

original: Ahañca puttā ca patī ca mayhaṁ,
translated: I and my children and my husbands,
Through compassion for our friends, we are complete.
Because of the king’s power and the hero’s power,
These things happen to one who has excellent friends.
He, having friends, having fame, having risen high,
Rejoices in this world, enjoying sensual pleasures as he wishes.
Friendships should be made,
Even with the poor, Senaka;
See how, through compassion for his friends,
We are united with our relatives.
“The strong man who is wise,
who makes friends with the wise,
is happy in this world,
as I and you, Senaka, are.”
The Jātaka of the Great Bull (Third).
